abstract.p: Elaine Rowland and George W Gowen letters comment on May 13 travel article on St Petersburg, Russia

block.p: To the Editor: ''36 Hours; St. Petersburg, Russia'' (May 13) makes travel with children to St. Petersburg, Russia, sound as easy as a trip to St. Petersburg, Fla. Is there more than one Russia? This Russia sounds very much like Western Europe. The Russia I visited is very far away -- a miserable distance to fly with children -- and I can't believe the author recommended using Aeroflot, with its terrible reputation.

I didn't read anywhere in the article that the State Department and most Russians will tell you not to drink -- or even brush your teeth with -- the local tap water. Nor did the story include State Department warnings to get updated tetanus and diphtheria immunizations (and preferably immunized against hepatitis A, too) prior to the trip.

To the Editor: ''36 Hours; St. Petersburg, Russia'' (May 13) makes travel with children to St. Petersburg, Russia, sound as easy as a trip to St. Petersburg, Fla. Is there more than one Russia? This Russia sounds very much like Western Europe. The Russia I visited is very far away -- a miserable distance to fly with children -- and I can't believe the author recommended using Aeroflot, with its terrible reputation.

I didn't read anywhere in the article that the State Department and most Russians will tell you not to drink -- or even brush your teeth with -- the local tap water. Nor did the story include State Department warnings to get updated tetanus and diphtheria immunizations (and preferably immunized against hepatitis A, too) prior to the trip.

St. Petersburg also has a problem with beggars, pickpockets and muggers, not generally considered kid-friendly. And last but not least, the author minimized language barriers: the Russian alphabet is not the English one. Once I was off the beaten track, few people I encountered could communicate in English.

To the Editor: Having visited St. Petersburg in February 1994, I found the recent article on the city a testament to how much has changed in the now-tourist-and-free-enterprise-friendly town. 15 years ago, there were few cars, no limousines, few restaurants and somber citizens.

The winter when I visited was cold, damp and snowy, not flakes but little pellets of ice. It was also the 50th anniversary of the end of the siege of Leningrad. I couldn't help thinking of those 900 days immortalized by Harrison Salisbury of The New York Times, and I wonder how any travel writer today could take pen to paper without words honoring the citizens and history of that ravished city.

When we were there, my wife and I made a pilgrimage to the cemetery on the edge of town. Its row after row of somber rectangular memorials melted into the earth and the gray-white snow. No words were needed: the silence spoke of Mother Russia.
There was an amphitheater of sorts upon which was a gold and black wreath -- a tribute from the German Republic. We carried a small American flag and placed it on the cold stone.
